It is Reg Henaford
Quinn says it's more about who manages the Packers.
The team has an executive committee headed by CEO Mark Murphy.
Then there's a board of directors and another board that manages revenues from the stadium.
Contrary to popular belief, the city of Green Bay does not own the Packers.
Though, taxpayers are helping foot the bill for those stadium renovations.
Unlike other professional sports, the NFL has a strict agreement sharing money made from television.
In addition, each team relies on things like merchandise and ticket sales to create revenue.
Quinn says that's how the small city Packers are able to manage themselves almost as a nonprofit organization funneling money into players' salaries.
He says people don't buy Packers stock as part of a portfolio.
You get a piece of paper you can frame on your wall.
You don't get free tickets.
You don't get to sit in the owner's box.
You don't get to meet the players anymore than, really, any other fan does.
But fans of other teams can't also brag about being an owner.
For NPR News, I'm Patty Murray in Green Bay.
As expected, the House of Representatives has voted to repeal the health care law.
The vote comes after two days of debate in which Republicans, one by one, took the floor to push for repeal.
I think it's time we return this House to the people and we can start by repealing the job-killing, socialistic, and out-of-touch health care bill.
Democrats spent the day defending the law.
Here's G.K.
Butterfield, Democrat of North Carolina.
Mr.
Speaker, I urge my Republican colleagues to stop playing politics with health care.
Open your eyes and see the pain of America's working families.
The repeal effort is headed nowhere, since the Senate is not likely to support it and the president has vowed to veto it.
Nonetheless, during the debate, we've been hearing once again the major differences between supporters and opponents of the law, and it can be hard to make sense of it all.
So we've asked you to send us your questions.
And here to help us answer some of them now is NPR health policy correspondent Julie Rovner.
Hey, Julie.
Hey, Melissa.
